step.para: Prepare Environment for OpenStack and SES Cluster Integration
Using the steps defined in the "Gracefully Shut Down the Cloud" exercise, shut down the Cloud deployed on the deployer01, controller01, compute01, and compute02 VMs.
When the cloud is shut down gracefully power off the deployer01, controller01, compute01, and compute02 VMs.
Power on the storage-admin, storage01, storage02 and storage03 VMs to start the SES cluster.
Power on the deployer02 VM.
Initialize the Installer Environment for the SES Integrated Cloud
On the deployer02 node, while logged in as the root user, enter the following command to ensure the node is fully updated:
The node should be fully updated. If prompted to reboot, reboot the node and log back in as the root user.
Enter the following command to switch to the ardana user:
You should now be logged in as the ardana user.
Enter the following command to initialize the installer environment:

You should see some Ansible playbooks run resulting in green ok= messages and yellow changed= messages. (If there are any red failed= messages review the output of the commands to determine the cause.)
On the deployer02 node, open a web browser and point to http://localhost:9085. You should see the SUSE OpenStack Cloud Deployer screen.
Select the Deployment Model
On the deployer02 node, while logged in as the ardana user, open a terminal and enter the following commands to download the new example model onto the deployer node:
Enter the following command to extract the downloaded tarball:
You should have a new directory named small-scale-kvm-proof-of-concept. Enter the following command to remove the downloaded tarball (leaving the extracted directory):
The tarball should be gone.
. On the Welcome Screen of the SUSE OpenStack Cloud Deployer, click Next.
In the Choose and OpenStack Model screen, select Small Scale KVM Proof of Concept from the list of models. Press Next.
In the Cloud Model to Deploy screen, select Lifecycle Manager Nodes from the Mandatory Components list. Enter 1 into the Edit number of nodes text box.
Under Mandatory Components, select Controller Nodes. Enter 1 into the Edit number of nodes text box. Select Compute Nodes from Additional Components.
Enter 1 into the Edit minimum number of nodes text box. Press Next.
Configure Cloud settings (Cloud DNS, Hostnames, NTP)
In the Add Servers and Assign Server Roles screen, press Manage Cloud Settings.
Switch to the Cloud Configuration tab. Configure the settings as follows:
Press Save
Close the Manage Cloud Settings window.
Manage Cloud Settings (Disk Models)
In the Server and Server Role Summary screen, press Manage Cloud Settings.
In the Manage Cloud Settings window, switch to the Disk Models tab. You should see the following disk models listed:

If you do not see the LIFECYCLE-MANAGER-DISKS listed, continue with the next steps. If you do see these interface models, review each model configuration and make sure that it matches the configuration specified here.
Press Add disk model. Enter LIFECYCLE-MANAGER-DISKS in the Disk model name field.
Press Add volume group. Under Add volume group, enter the following:
step.screen: Volume group name: ardana-vg Physical volume: /dev/sda_root

step.para: To add a new logical volume, press Add logical volume. Under Add logical volume, enter the following:
step.screen: Logical volume name: root Size: 80 Mount: / File system type: ext4 mkfs command options: (leave empty)
step.para: Press Save. You should see the new logical volume listed under Logical volumen in Add volume group.
To add another logical volume, press Add logical volume. Under Add logical volume, enter the following:
step.screen: Logical volume name: crash Size: 15 Mount: /var/crash File system type: ext4 mkfs command options: -O large_file
step.para: Press Save. You should see the new logical volume listed under Logical volumen in Add volume group.
Save the volume group and disk model configurations.
Manage Cloud Settings (NIC Mappings)
On the Server and Server Role Summary screen, click Manage Cloud Settings.
In the Manage Cloud Settings window, switch to the NIC mappings section. You should see the following NIC mappings listed:
If you do not see any of these listed, continue with the procedure. If you do see these listed, review each NIC mapping configuration and make sure that it matches the configuration specified here.
In the Manage Cloud Settings â€“ NIC Mapping window, click Add NIC Mapping. Enter the following to create a NIC mapping for the controller nodes:
step.screen: NIC Mapping Name: CONTROLLER-6PORT Port Logical Name: eth0 PCI Address: 0000:00:03.0
step.para: Press + next to the port/PCI address line to add a line. Enter the following:
step.screen: Port Logical Name: eth1 PCI Address: 0000:00:07.0
step.para: Press + next again, and enter the following on the created line:
step.screen: Port Logical Name: eth2 PCI Address: 0000:00:08.0
step.para: Press + next again, and enter the following on the created line:
step.screen: Port Logical Name: eth3 PCI Address: 0000:00:10.0
step.para: Press + next again, and enter the following on the created line:
step.screen: Port Logical Name: eth4 PCI Address: 0000:00:11.0
step.para: Press + next again, and enter the following on the created line:
step.screen: Port Logical Name: eth5 PCI Address: 0000:00:12.0

step.para: Press Save to save the changes.
Configure Compute NIC Mappings
Repeat the previous step to create a new NIC mapping for the compute nodes Use COMPUTE-6PORT as the name. Use the same port names and PCI addresses as the controllers.
Configure Lifecycle Manager NIC Mappings
In the Manage Cloud Settings â€“ NIC Mapping window, use Add NIC Mapping to create a NIC mapping for the controller nodes with the following settings:
step.screen: NIC Mapping Name: LIFECYCLE-MANAGER-1PORT Port Logical Name: eth0 PCI Address: 0000:00:03.0
step.para: Click + next to the port/PCI address line to add a line, and add the following:
step.screen: Port Logical Name: eth1 PCI Address: 0000:00:07.0

step.para: Press Save to save the changes.
